posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: Hello, we are using a pigeon on our arm to detect the angle relative to the ground so that we didn’t have to screw around with an absolute encoder or something like that, or well, we tried that, but on the gearbox, on a 1:1, and there was too much slop to get that to work properly. Regardless, it is configured such that the roll axis is the direction of movement, how can we configure this so that the degrees it returns are continuous, rather than bound by -90: 90 (we stow further back ), how can we configure this such that the roll axis can do that? I see in the documentation that you can set a custom mount pose, but I haven’t seen a clear example for our use case. We can also mount it to the side of the arm if it’s not possible to configure it correctly.

posts.name: what?
posts.cooked: what motor are you using to drive the arm? in this case if you really cannot use an absolute encoder,  using the relative encoder built in to the NEO/Falcon would still be more accurate as well as much easier to use than a pigeon

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: We are using falcons and plan to potentially use motion magic (we are using a wpilib profiled pid controller right now) but we have found that the pigeon works great and is extremely accurate and is continuous as long as it’s within the bounds. And I believe a bandaid fix would be to configure the mount pose such that it thinks it is vertical and is grabbing the typical roll axis as yaw but I was just wondering if there was a more proper way.

posts.name: what?
posts.cooked: could you show me your code and arm setup? I’m not sure I understand exactly how your using the pigeon

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked:
I don’t have access to the code or robot at the moment, but here’s a crappy drawing of what the setup is. image 779×371 5.49 KB we are calling get roll in the code right now.

image 779×371 5.49 KB

image 779×371 5.49 KB

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Can you just mount it on the side and use yaw instead?

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: we can, yes. Question with that case though, when our arm is parallel with the ground, roll reads 0. will that be the case if configured properly with yaw? Or will we have to 0 the pigeon somehow?

posts.name: what?
posts.cooked: another idea that might need a bit more math is that you could use the accelerometer to calculate your arms angle though it might be less precise

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: I’m honestly not sure, but that’s a really good point. You could zero it with the accelerometer.

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: After looking through the documentation it seems as though it zero’s based off of its mount position, so I think if we just flip the orientation in phoenix tuner or physically we will get an “absolute” position. Thank you for your help and suggestions, I won’t be back in the shop until Monday, but I’ll keep you posted. Thanks!

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: Well we couldn’t trick it into thinking the roll axis is yaw, so our plan is to remount it!

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: Why not just use Yaw then?

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
67 used a gyro on their arm in 2019 - there was no hard stop or easy way to locate it for initial position, so we used gyro angle to find the starting position of the arm and then used an encoder for control. While a gyro can be used for position control, it is more likely to see noise and / or drift over a match than a motor encoder, especially when impacts from defense happen. Have you tested what the gyro reads when you drive around? We found the gyro was too noisy to rezero the arm while driving, but worked well in a static situation (we had some ESD or brown out issues with the encoder and canifier that we never fully root caused, but had a need to occasionally rezero the arm in a match). I don’t remember what gyro we used at the time, but I’ve heard the pigeon 2 is significantly better than what was available then so maybe it just works now.

Edit: Also, the field isn’t flat this year, you may want to look at the difference between two gyros. One to use as a reference for robot level, otherwise your arm will drop when you drive on the charging station.

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
I just now noticed this thread, so I wanted to hop in and provide some insight.

asid61:

Can you just mount it on the side and use yaw instead?

Chadfrom7226:

Why not just use Yaw then?

This won’t work. Pigeon 2 follows the Yaw-first, Pitch-second, Roll-third convention, so Yaw is effectively the angle measured about the gravity axis. If the Pigeon 2 were to rotate, the yaw axis doesn’t rotate with it. It just adds an offset to the pitch/roll values.

What I’d recommend is using the gravity vector of Pigeon 2 to calculate the angle.

declaration: package: com.ctre.phoenix.sensors, class: Pigeon2

This has the added benefit of providing a nearly perfect feedforward scalar for the arm. If the Pigeon 2 is flat-and-level while the arm is flat-and-level, you can multiply the Z axis value by the feedforward term. As the arm angles up/down, the Z axis value follows the cos of the angle, which should match the desired feedforward.

Mike_Schreiber:

While a gyro can be used for position control, it is more likely to see noise and / or drift over a match than a motor encoder, especially when impacts from defense happen

While this is a good point for control of something such as a turret where the target angle is perpendicular to the gravity axis, it’s not as much of an issue for something like an arm, where the accelerometer provides an absolute point of reference that the IMU can fuse against. Gravity won’t change over time or with serious robot impacts, so the IMU never really drifts from it.

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: Does this mean that we can use the pigeon in its current orientation(as illustrated in an above post) and use the gravity vector in such a way? Is the gravity vector continuous - able to calculate any degree -180:180? Our stowing position is behind our “-90”. Thank you so much!

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
Yes, you can use the gravity vector for your arm with the orientation you originally had (or any orientation if you perform mount calibration), though it’s not continuous by itself. The gravity vector is purely a vector, so it won’t express the angle by itself.

You would find the arctan2 of the Z component and the X or Y component (depending on which one sees the rotation your arm performs)

In this case it’s Z and X, so the result is var theta = Math.atan2(zGravity, xGravity) , which will return a value between -pi and pi radians, providing full 360 degree knowledge of where the arm is.
